data.title: 24 Short Films Wes Anderson Wants You to See
data.meta_description: Wes Anderson lists twenty-four short films and anthologies that he recommends screenwriters and directors must watched watch.
data.text:
Perusing films is something that even the greatest filmmakers need to keep doing. Using other people’s art as a touchstone allows filmmakers to get familiar with their likes, dislikes, and personal motivations in their filmmaking. As true as it may be of any director, this rings true with Wes Anderson, whose love of movies is apparent in his work with actors and visuals in every production, no matter the runtime.

As a visual storyteller with features and shorts under his belt, Anderson’s taste is wide and varied. He has, of course, singled out a few that stand out the most to him. Anderson took to Letterboxd to list 24 short films that are on his must-watch list.

From an old-school cartoon that has charmed millions since the 1950s to various collections of shorts from directors across the ages, this list of works is well worth watching. Don’t take our word for it—take it from Anderson!

Read More: The Fascinatingly Small Worlds in Wes Anderson Films

Short Films Recommended By Wes Anderson

Simon of the Desert (1965) | Directed by Luis Buñuel, Written by Luis Buñuel, Julio Alejandro

The Postmaster (1961) | Written and Directed by Satyajit Ray

Vive Le Tour (1962) | Written and Directed by Louis Malle

The House Is Black (1963) | Written and Directed by Forugh Farrokhzad

The Gold of Naples (1954) | Directed by Vittorio De Sica, Written by Vittorio De Sica, Cesare Zavattini, Giuseppe Marotta

Christo’s Valley Curtain (1974) | Directed by Albert Maysles, Ellen Giffard, and David Maysles

The Girl Chewing Gum (1976) | Directed by John Smith

Ready… Set.. Zoom! (1955) | Directed by Chuck Jones, Written by Michael Maltese

Rue Saint-Denis (1965) | Written and Directed by Jean-Daniel Pollet

Powers of Ten (1977) | Directed by Charles Eames, Ray Eames

Boccaccio ’70 (1962) | Directed by Federico Fellini, Vittorio De Sica, Luchino Visconti, Mario Monicelli, Written by Federico Fellini et al.

Peter and the Wolf (2006) | Directed by Suzie Templeton, Written by Sergei Prokofiev, Suzie Templeton

Paris, Je T’Aime (2006) | Isabel Coixet, Christopher Doyle, Tom Tykwer, Joel Coen, Ethan Coen, et al., Written by Isabel Coixet

Passionless Moments (1983) | Directed by Jane Campion, Gerard Lee, Written by Gerard Lee

The Ballad of Buster Scruggs (2018) | Written and Directed by Joel Coen, Ethan Coen

New York Stories (1989) | Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, Martin Scorsese, Woody Allen, Written by Francis Ford Coppola, Woody Allen, Sofia Coppola, Richard Price

Very Nice, Very Nice (1961) | Directed by Arthur Lipsett

The Responsive Eye (1965) | Directed by Brian De Palma

Six Shooter (2004) | Written and Directed by Martin McDonagh

Antoine and Colette (1962) | Written and Directed by François Truffaut

Aria (1987) | Directed by Jean-Luc Godard, Bruce Beresford, Robert Altman, Nicolas Roeg, Julien Temple, et al., Written by Bruce Beresford, Robert Altman, Nicolas Roeg, Julien Temple, Ken Russell, et al.

Toby Dammit (1968) | Directed by Federico Fellini, Written by Federico Fellini, Bernardino Zapponi

Le Plaisir (1952) | Directed by Max Ophüls, Written by Max Ophüls, Guy de Maupassant, Jacques Natanson

Mystery Train (1989) | Written and Directed by Jim Jarmusch

—

Not every short on this list has the same goal, style, or creative background. Some are closer to recognizable narratives, while others are experimental vignettes or bordering the line of documentary work. Those differences help to enrich a storyteller, and Wes Anderson—like other filmmakers—chooses to celebrate those enrichments, using them to inform and inspire his work.

If you are looking for something new, something fun, or something to inspire your filmmaking, start by sitting down with the shorts on this list!
